etymology.description: Originally: semantic 爪 (“hands”) + phonetic 角 + semantic 女; later: 母 (“mother”) + 中 + 女 (“daughter”).
etymology.interpretation: Early forms used 爪 and 女 as semantic hints while 角 supplied the sound value; the original sense is uncertain. Later scribes reinterpreted the graph as 母 + 中 + 女, evoking a mother and daughter centered together, a purely graphic/ideogrammic analysis rather than a phonetic one.
etymology.simplification: Traditional 婁 was condensed to 娄 by streamlining and merging strokes into a compact phonetic skeleton, dropping the explicit semantic elements to create a lower-stroke form used widely as a phonetic component.

examples.chinese: 今天讲解昴宿和娄宿(今天講解昴宿和婁宿)。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān jiǎngjiě Mǎo xiù hé Lóu xiù.
examples.english: Today we explain the Mao mansion and the Lou mansion.

examples.chinese: 娄先生来了(婁先生來了)。
